name: Who Wants Creme Brulee? Quiz | Food & Drink | 10 Questions

questions.text: What do creme brulee and Mexican flan have in common?
questions.explanation:
They're both baked custards.

	Creme brulee (KREM broo- LAY) is the quiz writer's favorite dessert.

questions.text: What do tater tots, latkes, and pommes de terres frites have in common?
questions.correct: All have potatoes as the main ingredient.
options: All are fried in chicken fat.
questions.explanation:
All have potatoes as the main ingredient.

	Latkes are potato pancakes commonly eaten on Hannukah. Tater tots are potato blobs beloved by children. Pommes de terres frites (pum da tear FREET)are French fries (French ones).

questions.text: What do cornichons, chow chow, and senfgurken have in common?
questions.explanation:
All are pickled.

	Cornichons (corny-SHOWN)are tiny French pickles. Senfgurken are yellow cucumber pickles. Chow chow is a mixed pickle concoction.

questions.text: What do red beans and rice, Andouille sausages, beignets, hush puppies, and etouffee dishes have in common?
questions.correct: All are commonly found in New Orleans
options: All are commonly found in Quebec
All are commonly found in France
All are commonly found in Denver, Colorado
questions.explanation:
All are commonly found in New Orleans.

	Savory red beans and rice is a favorite in New Orleans. This dish is sometimes accompanied by spicy Andouille (on DOO ee) sausages. Beignets (ben-YAY, a doughnut-like dessert served warm with powdered sugar) can be munched at NO's famous Cafe du Monde, accompanied by their delicious chickory-flavored coffee. Hush puppies are cornmeal fritters traditionally eaten with fried fish. Etouffee (ay too FAY) means 'smothered.' Crawfish etouffee is a popular NO dish.

questions.text: What do latkes, matzoh ball soup, gefilte fish, and kosher dill pickles have in common?
questions.correct: All are commonly offered in Jewish delis.
options: All are commonly offered in Scandanavian restaurants.
questions.explanation:
All are commonly offered in Jewish delis.

	Traditionally, matzoh balls are made with matzoh meal, eggs, and chicken fat. A good matzoh ball is tender but does not fall apart in a steaming bowl of chicken soup.

questions.text: What do croutons, dumplings, matzoh balls, and gruyere cheese have in common?
questions.correct: They may all be eaten in soups or stews.
options: They are all commonly eaten in green salads.
questions.explanation:
They may all be eaten in soups or stews.

	French onion soup usually has a top layer of bread or croutons and melted, toasted gruyere cheese. Some stews are served with dumplings floating in them. Jewish chicken soup is often served with matzoh balls.

questions.text: What do Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc, and Gewurtztraminer have in common?
questions.explanation:
All are white wines.

	Gewurtztraminer is the sweetest of the three, but a Gewurtz can be earthy and complex as well as sweet.

questions.text: What do meringues, macaroons, souffles, and angelfood cakes have in common?
options: All contain either nuts or chocolate.
questions.explanation:
All contain stiffly-beaten eggwhites.

	Souffles can be savory (e.g. cheese souffles) or sweet (e.g. Grand Marnier souffles). Beaten eggwhites give these foods a lovely airy texture.

questions.text: What do basil, olive oil, pinenuts, garlic, and parmesan cheese have in common?
questions.correct: All are ingredients of pesto sauce.
options: All are ingredients of French onion soup.
All are ingredients of bearnaise sauce.
questions.explanation:
All are ingredients of pesto sauce.

	There are other pesto sauces besides the kind that features fresh basil. For example, one kind is made with sun-dried tomatoes.

questions.text: What do canellini, wax, navy, and kidney have in common?
questions.correct: They are all names for beans.
options: They are all names for lettuce.
questions.explanation:
They are all names for beans.

	Canellini beans are white (or beige) ones.
